bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, December 22, 1931

div1.p: Howard requests an interview with Moran in order to inquire about the yellow fever experiments. Howard is writing a play about the work of the Yellow Fever Commission entitled "Yellow Jack."

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to John J. Moran, December 22, 1931

opener.dateline:
157 EAST 82ND STREET
NEW YORK CITY
December 22nd, 1931.

div1.p:
Last week in Washington I talked about you with a friend
of yours named Parker to whom my friend General Kean sent me. I had just
been reading a very interesting letter of yours which was printed by a
man named Peabody in a pamphlet about the yellow fever story. The point of
my writing to you now is as follows.

I am a writer of all kinds of things, principally plays and talking
pictures. Some three years ago I hatched the idea of writing a play about
the yellow fever story in which you took such a part. I did not get much
encouragement from managers. You can readily understand that they had
very little faith in a show without love story and about so much sickness.
Last spring, however, while I was in Hollywood, I wrote a talking picture,
for Ronald Colman, based on Sinclair Lewis' novel, “Arrowsmith,” a book
which deals with the fight a doctor makes against the bubonic plague. That
picture has turned out to be one of the most successful movies of recent
years and audiences are intensely interested in the plague scenes. This
has given me the nerve to go back to my own idea and finish up the play
about yellow fever. I hope to finish it shortly, to put it on the stage here
late this spring or early next fall and to make a picture from it afterwards.

You can be of great help to me and it just happens that January tenth
is my wedding anniversary. My wife and I were discussing a short holiday in
honor of the event and wondering where to go. We haven't been in Havana for
a long time and it is a good town for a holiday. If you are going to be
there about that date and can spare time to talk things over with me, we
will come down there. I can get all the facts in the world out of books, but
the little details and anecdotes that make a story human never get written
down. In this story, because so many of the characters are still living,
I had rather have them right than make them up for myself.

I admit that it is unusual to tell a man that it is proposed to put an
actor up on the stage and in front of a movie camera with the express purpose
of impersonating him. It is enough to make any man uncomfortable. I dare say
it is the first time that a historical play or picture has ever been written
about living characters. But that is what I propose to do. There should be
a business side to my proposition, also. With luck, it may make a fair
amount of money which I am certainly prepared to share in return for assistance.

I wish you a very merry Christmas and shall look forward to hearing from
you regarding your plans for the days around January 10th.
div1.closer: Very Sincerely Yours, Sidney Howard. John J. Moran egy.
